portfolio.title: fresh8gaming
portfolio.summary: Custom built pattern library using atomic design principles. Heavy reliance on flexbox for dynamic element sizing, immense flexibility in switching out atoms in molecules for a fully dynamic ad. Built with Vuejs, this allows for any client brand coating to come from CMS, as well as atom/molecule configuration.
description: Core feature of the ads was the ability to edit their content on the fly from CMS and see the results reflecting live within seconds.

Originally, ads were built from a standard set of templates that were manually styled and tweaked based on client approved designs. This was a fairly straightforward but tedious process as both HTML and CSS were changing from ad to ad, requiring full testing coverage every time, including IE10+. Data was primarily server through a monolithic PostgreSQL database that required constant manual updates to setup the end product. There were also services like localization, classifier, and CMS. Each of them required their own individual setup for a new client.

One of the key goals for the rebuild was to simplify the rollout, cut down on code/testing/release time, essentially giving the product away to designers to be able to do the whole rollout from start to finish without involving developers.

We overhauled the entire front end and moved to Vuejs. We chose atomic design for our upcoming pattern library, breaking down our extensive ad building experience into key components that were the building blocks of new ads. Atoms were the smallest bits of data - indicators, logos, buttons, list items etc. And those were the building blocks of our molecule components, headers, footers, and main content blocks of the ads. The highlight of this was the exceedingly dynamic setup where each group of molecules could fit inside any ad size and consistently look good, thanks to flexbox styling.

Meanwhile backend was being segmented and broken up from a single monolithic database into a collection of microserices segmented in Docker components. A series of node scripts were added to generate folder structure and initial presets for new client build, which automated a huge amount of overhead. A lot of database migrations, and overwhelming amount of individual updates and datapoint creation for new clients were eliminated and grouped up into either scripts or linked services.
In the end, we cut our delivery time by almost 80%, coming down from over a month, to barely a week. It was a huge success.

portfolio.title: Element78
portfolio.summary: Original site was built with a rigid and - at the time - glitchy handlebars and mustache templating framework, with data coming from JSON. New site was rebuild with an in-house pattern library called Alloy, and using Umbraco CMS and .NET backend for dynamic data.
description: I had the honors of rebuilding the entire website as my first project as a new Middleweight developer at E78.
Rebuild involved a close collaboration with back end team to create and setup Umbraco, plan out necessary  input fields and data we want to show, and expose all the hooks for front end work

Once the planning and prototyping was done, and BE was being setup, I started working on FE. First thing was to familiarize myself with existing templating system, and while experimenting with it I found it limited and clunky, syntax and nesting had some bugs I had to work around. Then there was Alloy, a fully bespoke in-house styling library which I extended a little to include edge cases I found I needed for the rebuild and additional design layouts.

Once I did the basic setup on FE side, it was time to merge it with BE hooks and see the glorious half-styled data. This was also my first time adding Schema.org to the site. Alloy also had a lot of interactive elements such as sliders and accordions built in. In retrospect it was an in-house version of modern frameworks such as React and Vuejs.

A few weeks later Alloy and Umbraco were fully hooked together it was a simple cleanup to make sure its all running smoothly. Checking Umbraco UX side of things, iron out the kinks in how the data gets passed, optimize when necessary, rework when required.

The whole project, including learning time and optimization took almost two months, and in the end we had a brand new shiny website that looked almost identical to the old one, but was infinitely more reusable, much easier to update, flexible and a clean code to be proud of.

projects.title: SVG Moscow metro map
projects.summary: Heavily inspired by csstubemap, I thought that yes, HTML/CSS map is great idea, but on paper its completely unmanageable and unusable if you want to add any kind of data manipulation, sorting, shortest-path algorithms etc. After some research the only reasonable solution was SVG - a clean, clear, and elegant way of keeping the map maintainable without the hassle, its SEO friendly, its compliant with any standards, and its fully accessible to JS in a semantic and meaningful way, so data manipulation will be much more accessible and enjoyable task. I'm specifically interested in implementing A* search algorithm

projects.title: webGL 3D model manipulation
summary: Apparently I have a surprising passion for browser games done right. Most of browser games you see today are flash based, and anything even remotely close to webGL and HTML5 Canvas implementation is either nonexistent or done poorly and can barely be called a game. There are a few pleasant exception though, Play Canvas and Little workshop being the most notable ones.

I am exceedingly curious to play with this tech myself and see what I can do with this, how far can this be pushed, and even though JS is not an ideal language for expansive browser games - maybe a city management genre would fit it the best. So playing with a house model, setup its building order, 3D view and manipulation, hide/show individual elements etc. and maybe someday push it further than a single model.

projects.title: Pure CSS dynamic city
projects.summary: Heavily inspired by Tiny city, and as a healthy (but very unmanageable) alternative to webGL, this seems like a curious thing to try - create a few buildings, preset conditions and flexible variables, and generate a city based on set parameters. Yes its fairly basic, but how amazing would be it to create an always unique HTML/CSS city with a press of a button!

projects.title: Recreate Pillars of Eternity dialogue tree
projects.summary: A while back I've read very thought provoking article Designing Musical User Interfaces, I am not a designer, but it made me wonder when was the last time I used an audio file in my web development? In fact, was there even a first time? It seems baffling that such an obvious stimulus as sound is being completely ignored and even shunned in web development world. So I thought it would be an interesting experiment to combine a favourite characters dialogue - text and audio and interactions - with web development and audio files for an immersive experience. This will give me plenty of room to experiment with audio formats, and sound integration into a website.

projects.title: D3js family tree
projects.summary: Recently I have dabbled with D3js, an amazing and very powerful library for data manipulation. A complex tool that gives huge control over data formatting, outputting and shaping it in any way imaginable. This coincided with my personal curiosity for my family tree and finding lost relatives - there turned out to be a whole lot of them. The best way to visualise them all, keep a record, and present all the research and work done to all of them is a tree diagram. A very familiar and widely accepted genealogy depiction tool, and with proper formatting and rich data it can be a gorgeous and impressive data showcase.
